Headline.Para: GRAB-UBER MERGER; Recruiters pounce on Uber employees

LeadPara.Para: Headhunters say Uber badge makes staff hot property sought by rivals starved of tech talents

TailParas.Para: IN THE fast-paced world of tech, you lose if you snooze.

Tech giants such as Google and many others have already swooped in to lure several former Uber employees with job offers and interview opportunities, barely a day after the announcement of Grab's acquisition of Uber's Southeast Asian business.
The Business Times has learnt from sources that these offers did not just go out to those in the highly sought after digital fields, but staff in support functions as well.
Observers say that the frenzy to hire hardly comes as a surprise, as it is a "golden opportunity" for companies to snap up top talent from the available pool.

Andrew Chan, CEO of ACI HR solutions, observed: "There has been a shortage of skilled employees across Asia for a number of years now, especially those with strong technical skills as more companies embrace digital."

This comes at a time when Grab is still grappling with the transition, with 500-plus former Uber employees across Southeast Asia now under its charge. As of now, most of them are on paid leave until the company finds a role for them in the next three months.
Grab may have said that it "can definitely use all of the talented individuals in the Uber team", but the clock is already ticking.

A former Uber contractor said that job offers and interview invitations started streaming in fast and furious on Tuesday, including from firms such as Google, and a recruitment agent said to be representing Facebook.
Both Google and Facebook declined to comment.
Recruiters told BT they are well aware of many companies and agents who have either reached out to former Uber staff, or are planning to.
Adrian Tan, co-founder of HR consultancy The Resource Group, said: "Because of the lack of communication and information, Uber employees could be fearful and wavering. This makes them vulnerable."

He, along with other recruiters, is sceptical of Grab's claim to absorb all the employees. "There will definitely be layoffs, especially in shared services, where there are too many duplicates. You don't need two CFOs, for example."
The jobs offered by Grab might also not be aligned with what the staff want.

Assistant Professor Terence Fan of Singapore Management University noted: "Even after Grab reaches out to these ex-Uber employees, it is not obligated to offer jobs with the same pay or roles to them."
As Grab sorts out its teething problems related to the merger, other companies are seizing the opportunity to acquire skilled talent that they are sorely lacking.
Observers concurred that there is definitely a "war for talent" taking place, and that the ex-Uber workers are likely to be spoilt for choice as corporations vie for their attention.

Paul Heng, managing director of Next Career Consulting Group, said: "Uber is probably a good training ground for talent - be it digital, marketing, user interface and design, data analytics, sales and so on... As a matter of fact, I will be reaching out to them to see if they might have a sales talent for a client of mine who is starting a business."
Specialist digital roles such as software developers and data analysts are most likely targets of companies due to a dearth of such talent in Singapore, said recruiters.

This tech talent crunch has been widely discussed by the government and businesses over the past few months as it remains a bugbear in the tech industry, forcing firms to come up with new ways to secure the skills they need.
DBS recently announced that it plans to hire up to 100 tech talent through its recruitment hackathon programme Hack2Hire.

While it was coy about whether it is currently in talks with former Uber employees, its executive director for group HR James Loo said that the bank is always on the lookout for talents who possess the right skills, capabilities and mindsets.
"If there are bright sparks who meet these requirements, including those from Uber and Grab, we are open to having career discussions with them," he added.
Regardless of what the former Uber staff plan to do next, recruiters remain optimistic about their options.

The Resource Group's Mr Tan quipped: "I don't think the Uber folks affected by the merger need to worry. They have earned their stripes with their Uber badge. They will be highly sought after by many tech companies."
